results.title: Girl's sports: on the right track
results.brief_description: Considers the limited opportunities available to women who want to compete in sporting events. Shows how these limitations are being replaced by new opportunities for women in a variety of competitive sports including track and field. Through a short history of track and field, with original archive footage of Babe Didrikson and Wilma Rudolf, the limitations that were available for women to compete in sporting events are shown. The experiences of three high-school girls - a cross-country runner, a shot putter and a broad jumper - shows the new opportunities available for girls today.

results.title: Girl to woman
results.creator_credit: David Hilberman, Robert Churchill and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: Presents the changes of adolescence, from the superficial changes of growth, skin, body hair and body contour to the more complicated phenomena of glandular changes, sexual maturation, and the reproductive function. Throughout the film, individual differences such as those in rates of growth and in menstrual cycles are stressed as normal; the importance of sound habits of personal hygiene and health are highlighted. Also describes the male reproductive system. Narrated by Irene Tedrow.

results.title: Girl guides association international camp
results.brief_description: The first International Girl Guides camp to be held in Australia took place at Yarra Junction, Victoria, in January 1959. The film starts with the arrival of the guides who are from many countries, Great Britain, USA, NZ, and the Far East as well as all Australian states. Their life in camp is depicted and the international aspect emphasised by the exchange of signatures badges and by national dances. The Governor of Victoria, Sir Dallas Brooks, plays a visit to the camp and meets the leaders of each national group.

results.title: Girdle round the earth
results.creator_credit: Bruce Sharman, John Rowden, Peter Bradford and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: In 1820 Oersted discovered that a wire carrying an electric current has a magnetic filed which varies in accordance with the variations of the current. From this discovery the telegraph was developed; the Trans-Atlantic cable laid; the discovery of the telephone; and the advent of the radio. The cable and radio link should be supplemented by signals from satellites - thus the communication network is gradually encompassing the world.

results.title: Gippsland Honeymoon
results.brief_description:
A honeymoon couple tour the Gippsland area and admire the scenic attractions of the country-side. Depicts many of Victoria’s famous tourist attractions including: Lakes Entrance, Gippsland, Orbost, the Snowy River, the Tambo River, Bairnsdale, Omeo, Walhalla Goldfields, Buchan Caves, Mallacoota Inlet, La Trobe Valley, Glen Maggie Weir and Ninety Mile Beach. Produced in conjunction with The Tourist Development Authority and The Gippsland Lakes and Tourist Promotion Council.

This film was discussed on ABC Gippsland Radio on 14 March 2020. The following are comments for viewers which add insight into the film

Martin Richardson “Joe” is Joe Southon, from Paynesville who wasn’t actually a Lakes Entrance fisherman, but was the chosen “talent” for the movie - it was through his connections that the film crew came down here to make the movie. He was a farmer, part-time fisherman, and farm manager whose property occupied a large part of what is now the town of Paynesville. He was also involved in many civic roles around the Bairnsdale Shire. His daughter Beryl and son Bluey still live in Paynesville.

Ashley Meek My father features on this add fishing at the Glenmaggie spillway

Neil Walters who picked up one of the narrators was Ross Higgins. “put the money on the fridge wog.!” (Kingswood Country)

Graeme Nixon Cape Conran my dad jim nixon boat and me. Front boat

results.title: G.I.G.O.: garbage in, garbage out
results.creator_credit: Peter De Normanville, Michael Clarke and Millbank Films
results.brief_description: A film describing what computers will do and what they will not do, whether in controlling steel cutting, running a bank, making airline bookings or supervising a chemical plant.

results.title: The Gifted ones. - Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Don Haldane, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The gifted child, whose advanced mind distinguishes him from others of his age, is a valuable asset to society. Some say gifted children should be taught in a class of their own. Others say that the average classroom is better for them. The film presents the views of two prominent educators: Dr Florence Dunlop, Ottawa, and Dr. T.W. Martin, Toronto.

results.title: Gift of life
results.creator_credit: Don Murray, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: An account of the collections of blood from donors and its use in hospitals. Stresses the need for blood for transfusions every hour as part of medical service today; the procedure of voluntary donation, facilities provided and the careful labelling, testing and typing carried out by the Red Cross staff; the method of refrigerated storage and transport; use of separated components; an operation in process with the assistance of blood transfusions.

results.title: Gift for music
results.creator_credit: Peter Plummer and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: A visit to Chetham’s School of Music in Manchester, the first national co-educational school. Includes interviews with children who attend the school and discusses the problem of those who would like to study there but cannot. Considers the raising of school funds to educate talented children.
